body:
So I rebased my 8 long-standing PRs by the way.

Regarding this PR, compared to mine at #104, it seems that the allowed values behind :grab seems implemented differently, I think my approach in GrabCommand.groovy:buildSpec might be more versatile but maybe they are equivalent.

My Test class GrabCommandTest.groovy defines more test cases for that purpose. Adding those tests to this PR might help comparing the syntax capabilites.

Regarding the import completer, I believe my rescan command invokes a new reset() function in PackageHelper. I think you can copy those changes from #104, even if you leave out the rescan command.

The classloading seems to work btw, I can reproduce the behavior, so hopefully that means we can have the :grab command soon.

Still no solution for this one https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@groovy.incubator.apache.org/msg00983.html
btw, I notice the imports suggestions are not sorted, not sure since when. Looks messy.
@tkruse JLine is dead (as usual), so no idea when 2.13.1 will be released. :(. Do you think we should merge this anyway?
Oh... @tkruse ... should we take a look at the package import sorting while we're in here?
Yup— @tkruse 's `reset()` solution is far nicer here.

...and the tests fail if we don't implement `reset()` in the test...

The more I look, the more I'm liking Pull #104 .

Wow... that was frustrating.

I can't seem to find a way to get the general Grab() resolver to resolve remotes with only the `module` set in the dependency `Map`.  I don't... think it's possible?

So, it's looking more like we need to construct something that the Grape helper can get to— executing in a sub-shell call loses the classloader.

I'm going to try constructing the canonical short name again and reconstructing it with `GrapeUtil` again before the call.
I'm not a grape expert. In my opinion supporting the three and four argument version is sufficient. What do you think @paulk-asert ?

I think jline/jline2#208 is a bit annoying, but not terribly so. I guess there are no worse regressions in 2.13, given a glance at the bug reports.
On the other hand moving to Jline2.13 does not improve the behavior, just the codebase, I think.

So as a vote I'd say -0.
@Dispader There is no one argument grab version: https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/fd567f7e5cd9af35bd53a19af034a5520665b121

It would be nice if the same syntax as supported by `GrapeMain#install` was supported:
`<group> <module> [<version> [<classifier>]]`
It would also be nice to be able to specify a GrabResolver but that could be done as a separate PR.

Because many of the commits touch the same files it is difficult to review just the changes for the synthetic accessors/package-private.  I think for bulk changes like this, even if minor, separate PR's would be easier to review and manage.
@blackdrag @melix What do you think, should we merge this?

The change is not a binary compatible one... I guess the error reporter should have used that output to print the error messages to. So we can remove the property, but not in 2.4. And frankly, for 2.5 I think it should be deprecated only

Thank you all!

The problem here is that I've been wrong-headed about this— I've been trying to reproduce the behavior of Gradle, using the notation that gets passed in `dependency` sections.  (A mistake that Pull #104 isn't making.)

The way that this code was getting that job done was by putting the single-argument version of `:grab` through the `GrabUtil.getIvyParts` method.  I recall using the notation `@Grab('group:module:version')`.

But a Groovy Shell user can just type `@Grab('...')` right now— _that_'s what you were going for with the `:reload` command, wasn't it, @tkruse ?
One can't register as a listener for `ClassLoader` changes, can one?

Yes, the :rescan command was meant as a trigger to reload the definitions for import completion, after any action the user does to add files to the classloader (such as manually invoking grapes).

The way I knew about using grab manually in groovysh was this:
http://tech.puredanger.com/2010/03/01/groovy-grape-groovysh/
but apparently this may work too:
http://www.groovy-lang.org/mailing-lists.html#nabble-td4632257

However both are too clumsy for my taste to advertize them to novice users (in particular when having to additionally call :rescan next for import completion), hence my wish for a :grab command.

Is the only remaining problem the invocation of GrapeUtil.getIvyParts() and passing only a module name? 
I don't see too much value in reusing this function anyway. It seems that function is not particularly useful for the interaction case anyway, it returns an empty map in error cases. (Also the function is undocumented and I guess untested, as too much of the core groovy code).

I would recommend recreating the expression parsing logic even if that means having duplicate code.
In #104 I was not even aware of GrapeUtil.getIvyParts, else I would probably have copy&pasted it, and made the modifications needed for Groovysh.

Thanks! :+1: 

For next time: A pull request for master is enough, we will then port it to the bugfix branch our-self.

@blackdrag Thanks!

@yaccz  It would be nice if you would update the pull request to restore the getter and setter and deprecated it. Then we will merge. Thanks!

I agree in the future I would prefer separate PR's.

Can you please squash c7fec364237ff496c88d7018b436254bb5b26945 and fcbe33e2e9abcaaed0d0c7b273ff810f5acbb9e6? Thanks!

Yes I already realized this was a bad idea. I would've love to just fixup the initial scope changing commit, but could not do so without major effort because it conflicts with the other commit adding final here and there, that has been done in the meantime :-/

Another problem with doing so many changes is that there are a lot of merge conflicts when I try to merge the changes into the 2_4_X branch, but without merging it's highly likely that there will be conflicts when backporting bugfixes. :(

If you want I can go through again and restructure the changes. How do you like it? Individual PRs for each of the commits (except the fixup)? Should those individual PRs only contain one commit each, or do you like it to be split up by some metric?

No further thinking about it I'm not sure if multiple pull request will really help in this case. I guess the pull request would have massive merge conflicts with each other.

I think 69ade9eb71829395e798fd8ba6395287bc44940a it the most valuable commit, because removing code dead code is good for readability and maintainability. I do not know if there is an easy way to untangle it from the rest? c3ad8298bd817e43fd0f56cb898fbce647002298 is also nice. Of course the other commit also have value.

I think that bulk refactorings like these are best done one at a time (serially) with each as it's own PR with a single commit focused on the one change and agree that the unused code commit would be a good one to start with.  For me I'd wait for it to be merged before starting work on the next PR if lots of the same files are to be touched, and work on them in order of most likely to least likely to be merged.  I think that would avoid the headaches of dealing with merge conflicts.
@PascalSchumacher done.
Thanks!
I merged the pull request and did the updates Paul requested. Thanks! :+1:

Well there are also some bugfixes in jline 2.13.

Getting rid of most of the patched classes is very nice.

And I do not like to keep around so many unmerged pull requests.
Thanks Thibault! :+1:
@oreissig I rebased the remove unused code commit. Thanks!
TravisCI just timed out. I don't think my changes introduced a performance penalty that's responsible for that :)
Thanks!

Yes, that is highly unlikely ;) :).

I you like you can always make travis retest the pull request be using `commit --amend` e.g. with an empty commit and then force pushing e.g.`push -f`.
Thanks for the tip using `--amend`!

Yeah, the place that got me started on this track was Grab command was the [Grape documentation](http://docs.groovy-lang.org/latest/html/documentation/grape.html#Grape-UsingGrapeFromtheGroovyShell).  That led me to the same conclusion sounds like you came to: it's confusing for new users, and still quite a bit of keyboarding even when you know what you want.  It's just a bit ham-handed for my tastes, as well.

The approach I took was that I was looking for something that was playing the role of supplying things that would be understood by the [Grab Annotation](http://docs.groovy-lang.org/latest/html/documentation/grape.html#Grape-Annotation).  That seemed like something that might be familiar, and didn't ask too-too much from the user.

Thus, my original tests for acceptance were 1) passing in things that the annotation could accept and 2) getting added packages to the `import` command's completion.  That's where the `GetIvyParts()` bit came in— the `Grab` Annotation class was looking for either the map... or the short form, but neither is really open to being called from the outside world, but `GrapeUtil.getIvyParts()` seemed to be.

The `GrapeUtil.getIvyParts()` call seems to chop either the `abbreviated` forms (e.g.: `'com.google.guava:guava:19.0'`, things that come back from [these kinds of searches](http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.google.guava/guava/19.0#gradle)), and value-type part calls (e.g.: `:grab com.google.guava guava` assumes the only two-part dependency that Grape would take, `group` and `module`; and `:grab com.google.guava guava 19.0` would take the only three-part.)

I don't know if that's the _right_ way to go, but it's what I was going for.

(I see the `:rescan` command gives a lot of power to the user in it's own right (it'll at least... make the runtime environment look consistent?)  And I'd _love_ to see the `rescan()` method called on all changes to the parent classloaders of the shell, but I'm not finding a way to passively listen for changes to a classloader tree.)

(FWIW, I figured out how to pull and build the branch from Pull #104 — and spent a few hours trying to modify the `buildSpec` to take the Annotation short-form, but I ran into a problem: the `buildSpec` there presumes we can issue the arguments to `Grape.grab()` from a shell runtime environment.  So, we can modify it, but we can't then pass the shell's parent classloader, so `rescan()` wouldn't pick it up (without, of course, modifying Grape).  And I get the feeling that's what's been holding up #104 from being merged.)

So— sorry for the long post— and sorry it's been a few days since I could get back to this, but what do folks think of trying for this as a target contract?
- `:grab` with one string argument
  - attempts the Annotation short-form (Gradle form)
- `:grab` with two string arguments
  - that don't represent Groovy Maps
    - attempts the two-argument version of the Grab install in fd567f7
  - that do represent Groovy Maps (e.g.:
    - `:grab [group: 'com.google.guava'] [module: 'guava']` or
    - `:grab [[group: 'com.google.guava'] [module: 'guava']]`
      - attempts the two-argument map version of the Grab install in fd567f7
- same as above, but for the three-argument constructor with `version`
- same as above, but for the four-argument constructor with `classifier`

If I hear a `yea` or two, I'll start work on the above.

Yes, +#104 could not be merged because it had to modify Grape to work with a rescan.

> :grab with one string argument
> attempts the Annotation short-form (Gradle form)

Consider the unit tests from #104, they test these arguments:

```
// one argument
assert 'group:\'\', module:\'foo\', version:\'\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec(['foo'])
assert 'group:\'\', module:\'foo\', version:\'\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec([':foo'])
assert 'group:\'\', module:\'foo\', version:\'\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec([':foo:'])
assert 'group:\'foo\', module:\'bar\', version:\'\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec(['foo:bar'])
assert 'group:\'foo\', module:\'bar\', version:\'baz\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec(['foo:bar:baz'])
// two arguments
assert 'group:\'foo\', module:\'bar\', version:\'\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec(['foo', 'bar'])
// three arguments
assert 'group:\'foo\', module:\'bar\', version:\'baz\'' == grabCommand.buildSpec(['foo', 'bar', 'baz'])
```

Not sure if that's what you were going for. But a subset would also work, this can later be extended as users play with it and come up with ideas for how to speed up their workflows.

#104 does not consider the 4-argument case merely because I did not know about that possibility.
In my opinion `:grab 'foo:bar:1.0'` should work as the absolute minimum. Then I would add support  for `:grab 'foo:bar:1.0:jdk7'` and for `:grab 'foo:bar'`. Anything else e.g. maps is optional.
Thanks!
With the exception of a few changes to protected fields, it looks good to me.  With such a large change I would be curious what others think.  Hopefully get some to comment here.
I'm curious, what is the benefit of making this change?
I'm worrying about that this change might break some reflection code.

I agree with @jwagenleitner. We cannot merge this pull request as it is right now.  Frankly I prefer doing a change to final only if I mean to have it final. If for example all but one field is mutated from different places, then making that one field private does not really serve any purpose. Anyway... this should be done only for private fields. Fields of private inner classes are probably save, at least if not written in Groovy.
Yeah this has huge implications to Groovy libraries and could break existing code
I'll revert the changes to any non-private fields. I agree that we should not change any signiture that's available to others, even if they are unlikely to rely on that.

frankly I would not have merged this PR. There are checked exceptions removed from public methods. This is an incompatible change, because Javacode using that method and having a try-catch for the exception will no longer compiler, as we then suddenly try to catch an non existing checked exception. 

And there is this revert... I am not finding that code in this pullrequest, so I am wondering where this actually comes from

Sorry, there were two similar pull request. This one and 78b6cc54af85988829ecd6120b69f65e0d9a8ade. I mixed them up. 

I know that removing exceptions from signatures is not java source compatible. If you think that keeping this compatibility is important for these classes/methods we can revert both commits.

Done reverting.

I'm not quite sure about the argument with Groovy ignoring the private flag, making this change potentially breaking. By this logic, every change that does not merely add new classes is a breaking change. Maybe we could treak the groovy.\* package different than org.codehaus.groovy.*, with the former employing an even stronger compatibility contract?

The benefit is limiting the possible scope of influence a certain piece of code can have, similar to making stuff private or final. It does not have an immediate effect, but helps distinguishing different concerns (e.g. most private static methods are just little helpers that were not generic enough to be part of a standard library, but nevertheless contain functionality that is not dependent upon the particular object they are used by). This separation of concerns can help programmers comprehend the code better and may even help the JIT make certain assumptions optimizing bytecode.

I admit that any way the impact will probably not be substantial.

Thanks @oreissig I appreciate the explanation.  I agree that it can be a useful indicator for those reading the code.  For me I am not sure if that benefit is worth the change (though I'm kind of leaning towards yes), I would be curious to know what others think.

Groovy does not ignore private, but private has slightly different semantics in Groovy if compared to Java. I mentioned inner classes only because of some quirks there that may have a different effect from what you expect.
If you want to change something that has been available in a non-private context, then we have to discuss each and every case.

All right, then, I've sketched out test specification on a test truss class.  It tests the private `dependencyMap(String)` method just now, which I'll fix and change to a test on the caller.  For now, it should demonstrate a test of producing a `Grab`-consumable `Map` from a single-argument input.  Hopefully that'll be a bit more clear.

I'll propose:

``` Groovy
import spock.lang.Specification

class GrabCommandSpec extends Specification {

    // this test acts on a private method -- if this test ever fails, DELETE IT
    def 'creates valid depenency maps when passed valid inputs'() {
        expect:
            GrabCommand.dependencyMap(input).group == group
            GrabCommand.dependencyMap(input).module == module
            GrabCommand.dependencyMap(input).version == version
            GrabCommand.dependencyMap(input).classifier == classifier
        where:
            input                                  | group             | module     | version | classifier
            'net.sf.json-lib:json-lib:2.2.3:jdk15' | 'net.sf.json-lib' | 'json-lib' | '2.2.3' | 'jdk15'
            'net.sf.json-lib:json-lib:2.2.3'       | 'net.sf.json-lib' | 'json-lib' | '2.2.3' | null
            'net.sf.json-lib:json-lib'             | 'net.sf.json-lib' | 'json-lib' | '*'     | null
    }

    // this test acts on a private method -- if this test ever fails, DELETE IT
    def 'throws IllegalArgumentException when passed invalid inputs'() {
        when:
            GrabCommand.dependencyMap(input)
        then:
            thrown IllegalArgumentException
        where:
            input << 'net.sf.json-lib'
            input << 'json-lib'
            input << ''
            input << null
    }

}
```

One note: the test differs from the `buildSpec` test in #104 because direct calls to `Grape.grab()` require the `Map` inputs.

Iffn we think this describes a decent behavior, I'll shine it up and move it into the test tree.  (I'll also convert it to a `GroovyTestCase` and subclass `CommandTestSupport`, to keep it consistent with the rest of the test tree.)

So you are basically referring to [this issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-1591)? From what I am reading the "slightly different semantics" means "private is respected with `@CompileStatic` and accessible as if it were public for dynamic Groovy".

Do you mean this change is only safe for private inner classes?

Spock spec looks nice, but groovy core code should not depend on Spock, btw, so you cannot actually use it in the PR.

In contrast to Pascal I really would love to see support for providing just the module name. The main purpose of groovysh is to enable users to very quickly hack something instead of firing up an IDE. In particular since we cannot offer tab completion. It feewls wrong to have to type out `:grab org.springframework.boot/spring-boot-starter-web` when just `:grab spring-boot-starter-web` is realistically sufficient.

Now that you mention it `private static synchronized` somehow reads better than `private synchronized static`. I'll change it.

@pfmiles When calling private methods from (dynamic) Groovy, it should not matter whether a method is static or not. Statically compiled Groovy doesn't allow calling private methods anyway, so this should only apply to directly using the Java reflection API for invoking private stuff. Do you think this is a concern we should leave stable between minor increments of Groovy?

@tkruse As I said, I've no intention of including a Spock test here— and I'd translate it to a `CommandTestSupport`.  The only thing I was going for with the above was to get us to hone in on what we'd like to send to `Grape.grab()`.  Also why I just added as a comment here.

I think we agree on the spirit of the thing: the less a user has to type when they're extemporizing with the shell, the better the experience is going to be for everyone.  (And I couldn't agree more: I'm half into trying to create a completer that can pull in some kind of `group` and `module` for tab completion.)

But­— I don't really understand "to have to type out :grab org.springframework.boot/spring-boot-starter-web when just :grab spring-boot-starter-web is realistically sufficient".

I... really don't know any way to iden a `module` without the `group` at this time.

This may be my fault, and I'll try to be clearer.  The `Grape.grab()` method I'm trying to use won't resolve `module` without `group`

```
groovy:000> import groovy.grape.Grape
===> groovy.grape.Grape
groovy:000> dependencyMap = [module: 'spring-boot-starter-web']
===> [module:spring-boot-starter-web]
groovy:000> classloader = ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader()
===> sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader@33909752
groovy:000> grapeArgs = [classLoader: classloader]
===> [classLoader:sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader@33909752]
groovy:000> Grape.grab(grapeArgs, dependencyMap)
ERROR java.lang.RuntimeException:
Error grabbing Grapes -- [unresolved dependency: #spring-boot-starter-web;latest.default: not found]
groovy:000> dependencyMap = [group: 'org.springframework.boot', module: 'spring-boot-starter-web']
===> [group:org.springframework.boot, module:spring-boot-starter-web]
groovy:000> Grape.grab(grapeArgs, dependencyMap)
===> null
groovy:000> 
```

I got there by tracing the `Grab` annotation.  But even the `grab` command line utility doesn't seem to be able to resolve just the `module`

```
] grape install spring-boot-starter-web
install requires two to four arguments: <group> <module> [<version>] [<classifier>]
```

I'm completely in favor of making things as easy as possible on the end user, I just have no idea how to code a module-only implementation right now.  If you could help me understand better, that'd be great.

Haha, #104 tricks Grape! Try this:

```
groovy:000> import groovy.grape.Grape
groovy:000> Grape.grab(group:'', module:'joda-time', version:'')
```

It seems passing an empty string bypasses some validation maybe.

I don't know if I had done this intentionally in the past, or I never tried to pass a map without the empty string values.

No problem.
Maybe you could find a minute to help me with my problem with AST? ;)
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36030234/how-to-get-classnode-with-methods-code-in-ast-transformation
maciek
Dnia 14 marca 2016 21:05 Pascal Schumacher napisał(a):
 Thanks!—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
+1, nice catch

+1 for applying the slow variant (but with a test case please) and also preferably with missing rightShift and leftShift operations too. See GROOVY-7787 for a possible test case for leftShift. We can always work on a fast variant later.

Sorry, for not saying anything about this... I kind of lost this issue. It is possible the primopts code does not recognize register as long, since it is a closure shared variable. The class to implement the operators would be BinaryLongExpressionHelper... which has an implementation for ">>>", "<<<" does actually not exist. The bytecode you have shown is for the test method, but really interesting is the doCall method of the closure instead. Anyway... We can follow what Paul said

Weeeeird!

I can't get it to work, but I see the confusion now!  And if the empty-map-element works like above, the `buildSpec` in #104 would totally\* work.  (And we can easily build the empty elements into all the forms.)  Very\* nice catch.

Okay— so­— I can't\* get the above to work yet

```
groovy:000> import groovy.grape.Grape
===> groovy.grape.Grape
groovy:000> Grape.grab(group:'', module:'joda-time', version:'')
ERROR java.lang.RuntimeException:
Error grabbing Grapes -- [unresolved dependency: #joda-time;latest.default: not found]
groovy:000> Grape.grab(group:'joda-time', module:'joda-time', version:'')
===> null
groovy:000> Grape.grab(group:'', module:'joda-time', version:'')
ERROR java.lang.RuntimeException:
Error grabbing Grapes -- [unresolved dependency: #joda-time;latest.default: not found]
groovy:000> 
```

  but _something_'s going on here.  (The call-with-group in the middle was I thought we might need to have the package in the local Grab cache to pull it by module.)  But `Grab` over there is working, and I think it'd be _great_ to have a one-arg option (even if it does need to be loaded with a cache, it'd make using groovysh fast.)

  So— can you help try to figure what's special... like, how you're able to trick Grab in the shell over there?  If we can figure it out, I can try to reproduce it here.  I can't help but think that, since it does\* work somewhere, we can make it reproducible in the code.

Here's what my env in telling me I'm running, iffn it helps

``` shell
~){azazel}07:00P] groovy --version
Groovy Version: 2.4.6 JVM: 1.8.0_60 Vendor: Oracle Corporation OS: Mac OS X
(~){azazel}07:00P] groovysh --version
@|green Groovy Shell|@ 2.4.6
```

Hm, actually it does not work me for anymore, either.  I thought it was the empty strings that made it work back then, but apparently that wasn't it.
Maybe it depends on the remote server returning a result. Maybe that was the case for me back then, and they switched it off at maven central.

So I suggest going with Pascals suggestion to require group and module, and maybe when I find more time, I can figure out what went on back when I implemented #104
Thanks for the feedback. I reverted the changes I accidentally made to the Groovy class and changed the expression's behaviour to initialize its fields with null instead of empty list.
Good thing there are tests :) The `getString()` or `getValues()` methods of `GStringExpression` are actually assumed to not return null.
I missed that in the original code those were assigned where they were declared and that you had moved it down to the constructor.

not sure about this commit. You are right in that there is a builtin wrapper task and that our wrapper task should not be needed. But the soruce distribution comes without the gradlew files. So how does a user know what gradle version to use to ensure there are no problems with the built related to the built tool version? Right now we can tell people to use any gradle to execute the wrapper task and then work with the wrappers from there on

Thanks for the feedback. Actually I forgot about the source distribution. Why does it miss the gradle wrapper at all?

Now that you mentioned it, one of my previous pull requests removed the declaration of wrapper generation as default task in Gradle, thereby breaking the documentation describing the bootstrap of the source distribution. We should either
1. include the Gradle wrapper in the source distribution, or
2. change the README.adoc to call `gradle wrapper` instead of `gradle` (we may configure the Gradle version on the implicit wrapper task instead of defining our own).
merged, thanks

-1 on this change. Apache source distro's can't have the wrapper jar (a binary). They make some minor exceptions but to date the gradle wrapper isn't one of the allowable exceptions. The `downloadWrapper` task was meant to be a default task but that must have been overlooked in earlier commits. I just fixed that, so now the doco should be correct. This still leaves the implicit wrapper task with an explicit version free should someone wish to not abide by our recommendations.
I wonder why the Jenkins build failed so horribly. Can we trigger a rebuild, maybe by rebasing the PR?

Rebased and CI failed for jdk6 and passed for jdk7.  This is partly because the test in this PR (the one that failed) is trying to force a full GC and for jdk6 the failure was GroovyClassLoaders not collected by GC expected:<31> but was:<26>.

Thanks for the explanation.

I still think it is a good idea to not use a default task, so that Gradle prints a helpful splash screen when invoked without arguments instead of altering your working copy. I propose to document the use of Gradle's implicit wrapper task. Its version can still be overridden on the command line as described in the Gradle manual. I may also link to the Gradle documentation describing this use case in the README.adoc if desired.

I just found a way more in-depth explanation for the issue: http://www.beyondjava.net/blog/should-you-avoid-or-embrace-static/

> I recommend to use static as often as possible. There’s a twist: Never use `static` variables, but always use `static` methods.

Any opinions?
Not a good feature? Not a good implementation? Compatibility concerns? I'm open to criticism :)
Opened an issue for this PR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7802
Looks good at first glance. I'll try to go through it in more detail very soon.
Thanks! :+1:

@oreissig I honestly do not know. Sorry. :(

I'm hoping that @paulk-asert will offer his opinion of this pull request.
My pleasure!

will do soon - been a little busy ...

wrote:

> https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/265#issuecomment-204153126

Can you explain a bit what the motivation for this pull request is? I mean we do have a octals exactly the same way as Java. This would add another way, but with the problem that 0 and O are difficult to differentiate. On the other hand if you did write 0010 instead of 0O10 you would still get 8, so maybe it is not so bad. Still a bit explanation would be good. And not to forget... there should be a test for this

Awesome thanks for doing this! I'm not a Groovy developer, but I did look at the code and it looks like the changes I'd expect for this, but more so I can confirm the unit test added should both replicate the original bug as well as confirm the fix.
languages like python exclusively have 0o for octals, so it'd be easy for people from those languages to get adapted
I created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7808 since part of this fix includes having to change an existing test.  Will give it a couple days to see if there is any feedback.
@hlaaftana breaking language changes require more information, explanation and tests than simply saying Python does it, so so should Groovy

The python PEP: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3127 This also has the motivation:

> The default octal representation of integers is silently confusing to people unfamiliar with C-like languages. It is extremely easy to inadvertently create an integer object with the wrong value, because '013' means 'decimal 11', not 'decimal 13', to the Python language itself, which is not the meaning that most humans would assign to this literal. 

I am actually surprised they want to support 0O. It should also be noted, that they go with not supporting 010 anymore. I would have no problem supporting the 0o variant, but I don't like 0O at all. just using the leading 0 is also not that nice, so I am unhappy with the Java variant actually. Frankly I would have chosen a different letter like c instead. I mean it is x for hexadecimal, and only for binary it is b. I see no problem in using some letter different than o here... unless of course we want to align with python.

A bit google usage found me that not many languages support octal literals, C doesn't have them. Scala removed them and Swift for example supports only the version with small o. My opinion is, the Python people actually made a mistake for allowing 0O, 0o is ok, but is it ok to have 0O10 and 0010 at the same time? Python's answer seems to be no. The VHDL variant would be O"010", but there you really have a clear understanding what is prefix and what is number. 

So all in all I have no problem with allowing 0o for octals, I am against 0O as long as we have the version with the simple 0 prefix though
Thanks!
